data.title: Terminal fonts are "fuzzy"
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.17.0-insider (38853832f83c75a76412d3586dfb8bdeb97a8777, 2017-09-14T07:58:39.362Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.15063
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
Bookmarks|ale|0.16.0
project-manager|ale|0.21.1
vscode-eslint|dba|1.3.1
gitlens|eam|5.0.0
EditorConfig|Edi|0.10.1
prettier-vscode|esb|0.23.1
beautify|Hoo|1.1.1
vscode-stylefmt|mrm|2.5.0
atom-keybindings|ms-|3.0.1
vetur|oct|0.9.7
stylelint|shi|0.29.0
vscode-todo-highlight|way|0.5.11
vscode-jumpy|wma|0.3.1
---
Basically, the main editor uses subpixel anti-aliasing, making the font look good.
The terminal uses grayscale AA, making the font look fuzzy. I am using Fira Code Light.

Also, I didn't notice the fuzziness of the terminal fonts in the past, but in today's Insiders build it is very noticeable.

Here's the screenshot. It doesn't look *that* bad as compared to what I actually see on my screen :)

![vs-code-font-rendering](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/9781/30422187-77c394b4-993f-11e7-81aa-148d836655dc.png)

data.title: The "implement interface" quick fix is missing private fields
Partial staging stages additional (deleted) lines selects consecutive lines as well

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.16
- OS Version: Win10


Suppose I have 4 total changes: 1 addition and 3 deletions. All these lines are consecutive (so a one "hunk" in Git GUI)

I want to partially stage only the 1 addition. 

In Git GUI I would do this:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2523987/30419100-d3d90262-9952-11e7-96fa-2cf16dfb905e.png)

But in VSCode when I try to stage only the 1 addition, it stages the 3 deletions next to it too:


![2017-09-14_13-49-19](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2523987/30419417-da24cd62-9953-11e7-93c5-06ae9429c4fa.gif)

And when I try to unstage the 2 deletions it again unstages the 1 addition right before it as well:

![2017-09-14_13-49-48](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2523987/30419468-0f4c5e74-9954-11e7-92b3-4aef637b9a9c.gif)


Steps to Reproduce:

repro: https://github.com/laggingreflex/vscode-git-test

(Steps to Reproduce in repro readme)

data.title: Icons hidden in list of extensions but only on Linux
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.16.0 (787b31c0474e6165390b5a5989c9619e3e16f953, 2017-09-06T16:19:37.192Z)
- OS Version: Linux x64 4.10.0-33-generic

I recently installed VS Code on my Linux and for some reason the icons in the list of extensions are hidden. See the screenshot below.

![screenshot from 2017-09-14 10-13-14](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5500205/30419404-7cedc166-9936-11e7-8b91-a5963b9e5202.png)

I've checked the developer tools and I've found a css rule that hides them (in workbench.main.css):

```
.extensions-viewlet.narrow>.extensions .extension>.icon, .extensions-viewlet>.extensions .extension.loading>.icon {
    display: none;
}
```

This reproduces with and without extensions.

data.body:
In Visual Studio 2015 you can hold down ALT and select multiple lines to edit multiple columns.

you can also arbitrary select text in columns the same way, delete it or replace it. 

Its WAAAAAAY EASIER than creating more cursors like in VSCODE.

Column Editing like in VS2015 improve productivity, 

MAKE IT SO... please :)

data.title: Feature Request: CTRL + SELECT like in Visual Studio 2015
data.body:
in VS2015 you can select whole words by holding down CTRL and do selection, it's faster and easier !!

you can also CTRL + CLICK to select a whole word. 

MAKE IT SO ... please :)

data.title: Time is wasted when extension contribute configurations
data.body: When we read package.json-files of our extensions we also register new configurations. The profile shows that this triggers event to which various part of our core react. That doesn't make sense because a built-in, core component like the welcome screen should be influenced by a setting from extension foo. This needs * [ ] a fine-grained configuration change event that allows consumer to check what settings have changed * [ ] adoption in the listeners

- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---

jshint|dba|0.10.15
vscode-eslint|dba|1.3.1
python|don|0.7.0
vscode-html-css|ecm|0.1.8
file-icons|fil|1.0.5

debugger-for-chrome|msj|3.3.0
advanced-new-file|pat|0.5.0
hipsum|thi|1.0.7
lorem-ipsum|Tyr|1.0.0
vim|vsc|0.10.0

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create html file
2. Type "input:text" and press tab

Cursor is moved to type attribute that is already correctly filled in as text. Would be more appropriate for it to be moved to the name attribute. Seems to work correctly with other input completion such as input:date or input:color.

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Tab give incorrect indentation on Go file.
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.16.0
- OS Version: macOS Sierra 10.12.6

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Write go code
```golang
package main

func main() {
    bus := event.NewBus()

    var events []event.Event

    bus.Subscribe(event.HandlerFunc(func(evt event.Event) {
        events = append(events, evt)
    }))

}
```
2. Press "tab" key will give incorrect indentation only on the line 11.
Result will be like:
```golang
package main

func main() {
    bus := event.NewBus()

    var events []event.Event

    bus.Subscribe(event.HandlerFunc(func(evt event.Event) {
        events = append(events, evt)
    }))
        |
}
```
While expecting:
```golang
package main

func main() {
    bus := event.NewBus()

    var events []event.Event

    bus.Subscribe(event.HandlerFunc(func(evt event.Event) {
        events = append(events, evt)
    }))
    |
}
```
<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: vscode development - how to import a new npm module into vscode
data.body:
I'm developing a new feature to vscode itself. I want to use a  npm module(axios) in the source.

In the root of project,
```
npm install --save axios
```

Any in any typescript file of vscode, 
```
import * as axios from 'axios';
```
There's error: `[ts] Cannot find module 'axios'.`

But when I import other npm which is already in original vscode [package.json](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/master/package.json#L47) such as `winreg`. Then,  the statement`import * as winreg from 'winreg';` doesn't show any error.

Question: How do I import a new npm module into vscode?

data.title: Provide different settings for color picker and that square showing color
data.body: Right now in settings there is only one setting to toggle both color picker and that square which is shown at the left of the color. I found `vscode-colorize` better, which shows color behind the text and is better than a square which pops up everytime when it identifies a color. The problem is that I still want to use that in-built color picker, but as they are toggled with same setting I'm unable to do so.

data.title: Prepending current PATH to PATH defined in "terminal.integrated.env.osx"
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.15.1
- OS Version: macOS Sierra 10.12.6

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Update workspace settings to something like
```json
{
  "terminal.integrated.env.osx": {
    "PATH": "/home"
  }
}
```
2. Now open Terminal and look at PATH
```bash
echo $PATH
/usr/local/bin:/usr/bin:/bin:/usr/sbin:/home
```

On Windows, having the same setting will not result in the current `PATH` being prepended, but instead, just setting the path to whatever is defined in `terminal.integrated.env.*`

Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Seeking advice - is it ok to create a CompletionItem with a command that retriggers completion?
data.body:
Hi.

In my language service, I have some completion items that re-trigger completion using an associated `Command` on the `CompletionItem` that is implemented by my extension.

https://github.com/tintoy/msbuild-project-tools-vscode/blob/a4288d06830b9563a87496ff5b3eee2e7fa6ab92/src/LanguageServer.Engine/CompletionProviders/ItemMetadataExpressionCompletion.cs#L288-L298

Completion can be 2-phase in this context; I provide a list of completions and, if one of a subset of those completions is selected, then I re-trigger completion to provide the second piece of required information.

The extension itself does 2 things:

1. Watches for certain 2-character combinations, and triggers completion if they are found (auto-closing pairs in the language configuration does not seem to reliably support a multi-character opening).  
    https://github.com/tintoy/msbuild-project-tools-vscode/blob/a4288d06830b9563a87496ff5b3eee2e7fa6ab92/src/extension/extension.ts#L327-L336
2. Implements a command to move the cursor and trigger completion.  
    https://github.com/tintoy/msbuild-project-tools-vscode/blob/master/src/extension/internal-commands.ts#L24-L37

It seems OK to me, but it does feel as if I'm working around the way this was intended to be used; I'd just like to confirm that it is not considered being a bad citizen, extension-wise (e.g. bad for performance, etc). This functionality is only enabled when using a custom language defined by my extension, not any of the built-in ones, if that makes any difference.

data.title: Extension Development Host : No 'Save File' prompt on closing a modified file.
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.17.0-insider (2c385b98066eebb8e39dfd98b1fcb8cc254196b6, 2017-09-11T05:24:31.374Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.15063
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
gitlens|eam|5.0.0
azure-account|ms-|0.1.2
debugger-for-chrome|msj|3.2.1



---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Using Hello World, start debug mode. An Extension Development Host instance opens, with the VSCode home screen. 
2. Click on New File. Write something there, say, 'Lorem Ipsum'. 
3. Close the file (Ctrl+W). 

Expected : 
A system dialog prompt asking me if I want to save a file, warning me of unsaved changes. 
Result : 
File closes with no warning. 

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes/No

data.title: Add some sort of warning when file has changed from outside
data.body:
I'm aware you guys (@stringham) pulled off something very needed in [this PR](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/pull/29655). Thank you for that.

Still, unless the file change is something huge, I find myself coming back to the editor after working somewhere else and going to modify an additional piece of data in that file, without realizing that the file has changed, potentially messing the 'new' file and/or unknowingly overwriting it.

There should be some warning or prompt (like in other editors) to make it clear that the data has been updated from the outside.

Now, thanks to that PR I can either go back and save somewhere else or review the new changes from the outside... I have options. But **only if I know** that file has been reloaded. As it is now is very sneaky and error prone IMHO.
